title: 106_hr583
content: The Act may be cited as the "Assistant United States Attorneys Retirement Benefit Equity Act of 1998" and addresses the treatment of Assistant United States Attorneys. The Act, titled the "Assistant United States Attorneys Retirement Benefit Equity Act of 1998," amends the definitions of law enforcement officers in the Civil Service Retirement System and the Federal Employees' Retirement System to include Assistant United States Attorneys. The Act, titled the "Assistant United States Attorneys Retirement Benefit Equity Act of 1998," includes Assistant United States Attorneys in the definition of law enforcement officers in the Federal Employees' Retirement System. The amendments made by this Act will take effect on the first day of the first applicable pay period after a 90-day period from the date of enactment. SEC. 3. PROVISIONS RELATING TO INCUMBENTS. "An incumbent, defined as an Assistant United States Attorney appointed before the Act's effective date, can elect to be treated according to the Act or as if it had never been enacted. The Department of Justice must provide notice to incumbents regarding their election rights within 6 months of the Act's effective date." An incumbent who elects the option under subsection (c)(1)(A) will have all service performed as an Assistant United States Attorney treated retroactively. An election under subsection (c)(1)(A) will have retroactive effects on service performed as an Assistant United States Attorney. Additionally, the Department of Justice must make makeup contributions to the Office of Personnel Management. Makeup Contributions: The Department of Justice must remit additional individual and Government contributions to the Civil Service Retirement and Disability Fund for service performed by Assistant United States Attorneys before the effective date of their election under subsection (c), plus interest. The Disability Fund requires additional contributions for Assistant United States Attorneys' service before the effective date of their election, plus interest. The Act does not create individual liability for contribution shortfalls. The Office of Personnel Management will establish regulations for implementing the Act, including determining interest on contributions. The term "Assistant United States Attorney" refers to an assistant appointed under section 542 of title 28, United States Code.
